thread.title: NHL: Canadiens earn ninth straight win
thread.title_full: NHL: Canadiens earn ninth straight win | The Salt Lake Tribune

title: NHL: Canadiens earn ninth straight win
text:
Montreal • Even when the Montreal Canadiens get outplayed lately, they have Carey Price in net to save the day.
The Canadiens were outshot 52-27 by the Toronto Maple Leafs on Saturday night but Price's stellar goaltending and three special teams goals lifted Montreal to a 5-3 victory that extended its season-opening winning streak to nine games.
The Canadiens are a victory away from tying the NHL record set by the Maple Leafs in 1993-94 and matched by Buffalo in 2006-07. Their next game is Tuesday at Vancouver.
P.K. Subban and Max Pacioretty each had a goal and assist, while Lars Eller, David Desharnais and Brendan Gallagher also scored for Montreal, which already has an NHL-record nine regulation wins to start the season. 
  "Our goal is not to break records, it's to win a Stanley Cup," said Subban. "I think we'll save the champagne or whatever anyone expects us to do for another day."
Devils 4, Sabres 3 • In Buffalo, N.Y., Adam Henrique scored twice and added an assist and New Jersey won their its fourth straight. Mike Cammalleri had a goal and two assists, and David Schlemko also scored for the Devils. New Jersey hasn't lost since starting the season 0-3-1.
Buffalo lost Evander Kane to an apparent left leg injury midway through the third period. A high-profile addition last season, Kane needed to be helped off the ice and did not return.
Penguins 2, Predators 1 (OT) • In Nashville, Tenn., Phil Kessel scored 41 seconds into overtime to give Pittsburgh the win over Nashville. Chris Kunitz had the other goal for Pittsburgh, which won for the fourth time in five games. James Neal scored for Nashville, which lost at home for the first time this season.
Less than a minute into overtime, Kessel took the puck toward the Nashville net on the left side. His first shot was denied by Nashville goaltender Pekka Rinne, but he was able to tap the rebound in for the win.
Islanders 3, Blues 2 (OT) • In St. Louis, Mikhail Grabovski scored his first goal of the season 4 minutes into overtime and New York beat St. Louis. John Tavares scored his fifth of the season for the Islanders. Frans Nielsen had two assists, including on Grabovski's winning goal.
